dc:description: The relationship between PCDH15 and autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss (ARNSHL) was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of 12/8/2017. The PCDH15 gene has previously been classified as Definitive for Usher syndrome by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Expert Panel. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in phenotypic variability. Therefore, we have split curations for the disease entities of Usher syndrome and non-syndromic hearing loss. Variants in PCDH15 were first reported in humans with this disease as early as 2003 (Ahmed et al., PMID 14570705). There are many cases in the literature claiming non-syndromic hearing loss with PCDH15 variants however many of the variants were not scored due to lack of convincing evidence of pathogenicity or lack of information of phase. However, at least 4 unique variants (missense, in-frame indel, truncating nonsense, frameshift) with sufficient evidence to score reported in humans with sufficient electroretinography or age-dependent phenotyping to rule out Usher syndrome. These variants were detected in a large Pakistani family with non-syndromic hearing loss with no history of retinitis pigmentosa (RP) (age range 13-44) (Ahmed 2003 14570705); a Chinese family that was claimed to be non-consanguineous with non-syndromic HL (18 year old proband and 28 year old brother w/ HL)  (Zhan 2015 25930172); a 21 y.o. male noted to have no other symptoms (Wang 2017 28281779). There were some patients described to have no ERG's conducted so Usher syndrome could not be ruled out (Yang 2013 23767834). This gene-disease association is supported by expression studies and protein interaction studies (PMIDs: 25467981, 16807332, 11138007, 28263850, 14570705). However, many of the cases do not provide ages for individuals which makes this scoring susceptible to including cases that may develop late-onset RP. Therefore, the association between PCDH15 and ARNSHL is Limited. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Working Group on 6/19/2018.

evidence.dc:description: This model was not scored because of the vestibular phenotype. Additionally, it could be used as a model for Usher syndrome which has a more definitive association with PCDH15.

Humans with DFNB23 do not exhibit vestibular involvement, however this rat which has also been used as a model for Usher syndrome did. This rat did not have any retinal phenotype, however it could be used as  a model for usher syndrome which is a more definitive association for this gene.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kyoto Circling (KCI) Rat

evidence.dc:description: Syndromic features-vestibular dysfunction, could be model for Usher Syndrome, not scored
This mouse model cannot be scored because there are syndromic features
evidence.rdfs:label: Noddy Mouse

evidence.dc:description: The Ames Walzter mouse model is associated with Usher syndrome and therefore cannot be scored for ARNSHL
This mouse is considered to be a model for USH1 as well as DFNB23, however this model cannot be scored for nonsyndromic hearing loss because of its association with Usher syndrome
evidence.rdfs:label: Ames waltzer PCDH15 Mutant mice

evidence.dc:description: This mouse has been scored as a model for PCDH15 Usher Syndrome and should not be scored for ARNSHL

The mouse model could be used as a mouse model for Usher Syndrome. This model should not be counted for ARNSHL as it is an Usher model even though there is no mention of retinal phenotype. They previously reported in 1999 that this mouse displayed circling behavior
evidence.rdfs:label: Ames waltzer PCDH15 Mutant mice

evidence.dc:description: this mouse model was not scored because it could also be scored for an Usher syndrome mouse model because vision loss is not a requirement for scoring Usher mouse models.

Used ABR to detect that there was hearing loss. Also examined inner ear morphology and found that the hair cells were degenerated in the double heterozygous mice and that there was progressive hearing loss relative to age matched controls.
evidence.rdfs:label: Digenic Mice w/ Double Het CDH23/PCDH15

evidence.dc:description: The Ames Waltzer mouse model has already been scored for expression therefore this instance was not scored.
Found that there was no expression of RPE in the mouse model, and that there was inner ear expression however, this mouse model (Ames Waltzer) has already been scored for expression.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ames waltzer PCDH15 expression

evidence.dc:description: Northern blot and RT-PCR showed that the protein was expressed in the mouse inner ear among several other tissues. This is the only instance of counting PCDH15 expression in the Ames Waltzer model
evidence.rdfs:label: PCDH15 Expression Mouse inner ear

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence is already maxed out but this is further detail on the biochemical function/expression

Immunofluorescence study showing that multiple protocadherin-15 transcrips are shown to be expressed in the mouse inner ear. They also highlight some of the biochemical functions of the gene as they found that an isoform located the tips of stereocilia is sensitive to calcium chelation and proteolysis with subtilisin and reappears at the tips of stereocilia as transduction recovers after the removal of calcium chelators. Protocadherin 15 is therefore associated with the tip-link complex and may be an integral component of this structure and/or required for its formation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Transduction complex of sensory hair cells

evidence.dc:description: Used "laser capture micro dissection combined with NGS of cell type-specific deafnes gene expression in the mouse cochlea to detect many different deafness genes including PCDH15. It is also noted that PCDH15, among other syndromic HL genes was expressed 3x more in the spiral ganglion than in the other areas of the cochlea.
evidence.rdfs:label: Laser-capture micro dissection w/ NGS in cochlear cells

evidence.dc:description: Immunocytochemistry/immunogold electron microscopy as well as mass spec analysis  were used to identify protocadherin 15 in mouse hair cells. The paper identified several isoforms including 2 novel transcripts in the inner ear. They also found that PCDH15 localizes at the tip of the stereocilia and is therefore thought to be involved in the mechanotransduction involving its apparent chelation to calcium ions. Additionally, they were able to detect PCDH15 in the chicken utricle.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunocytochemistry in cochlear hair bundles

evidence.dc:description: The LHFPL5 protein is only moderately associated with hearing loss, and this mouse model has been implicated in Usher so this evidence could not be scored.

LHFPL5 has been implicated moderately with ARNSHL, however the gene must be definitively associated. Additionally, though this study showed spatiotemporal changes in the distribution of LHFPL5 mice in the absence of PCDH15, this study was done with Ames waltzer mice and therefore the phenotype of the mice cannot be counted as an animal model.
evidence.rdfs:label: PCDH15 and LHFPL5

evidence.dc:description: TMIE has been found to be definitively associated with hearing loss and was found to interact with PCDH15 in this study by using extracts from HEK293 cells transfected to express an HA-tagged version of TMIE together with PCDH15. More specifically, the PCDH15-CD2  isoform interacted with TMIE and the other two homogoues only interacted weakly.
evidence.rdfs:label: TMIE and PCDH15

evidence.dc:description: One frameshift in trans with a missense (p.T1373I) that has also been seen in trans with a different missense variant in a case from this same paper (Yang 2013). NO ERG'S DONT SCORE

evidence.rdfs:label: D349
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted sequencing of 79 known deafness genes in 125 deaf probands followed by Sanger confirmation
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Pre exclusion of mutations in GJB2, SLC26A4, MT-RNR1 by Sanger.

comprehensive auditory evaluation
was performed including otoscope examination,
tympanometry, pure-tone audiometry (PTA), auditory
brainstem response (ABR) in subjects with very young
age, and in some cases computed tomography (CT) of
the inner ear. The onset of hearing impairment was categorized
as prelingual/early (≤ 6 years) and late (> 6 years).
PTA was calculated as the average of the hearing level at
0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 4.0 KHz for the better ear. The severity
of hearing impairment was defined as mild (20~40 dB),
moderate (41–70 dB), severe (71~95 dB) and profound
(>95 dB). To enroll in this study, all probands should
have bilateral, permanent sensorineural hearing impairment.
The hearing level of the prelingual or early-onset
deaf probands should exceed 70 dB. For the late-onset,
progressive probands, their hearing level should exceed
40 dB at the age of 35 years.

evidence.dc:description: This variant is in an allegedly non consanguineous family but it is only one homozygous deletion and the only evidence for pathogenicity is that it is in an evolutionarily conserved domain and that there are multiple affected individuals with the variant. Therefore, it was downgraded to 0.25 pts. The variant is also present in 18 alleles in gnomAD w/ no homozygotes.

evidence.rdfs:label: GDSW24 II:4
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted NGS of 127 deafness genes followed by Sanger of variant.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
pure-tone audiometry
(PTA) and tympanometry and standard temporal computed
tomography (CT) were performed.

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous missense variants in trans with no further evidence other than computational evidence and absence from freqeuncy in 200 Chinese Han hearing controls

evidence.rdfs:label: D121
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted sequencing of 79 known deafness genes in 125 deaf probands followed by Sanger confirmation
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Pre exclusion of mutations in GJB2, SLC26A4, MT-RNR1 by Sanger.

brainstem response (ABR) in subjects with very young

of hearing impairment was defined as mild (20~40 dB),
moderate (41–70 dB), severe (71~95 dB) and profound
(>95 dB). To enroll in this study, all probands should

evidence.dc:description: downgrade

evidence.rdfs:label: F9 IV:1
evidence.previousTestingDescription: GJB2 screening and clinical questionnaire to rule out history of other possible casuees of HL.

evidence.dc:description: Though the transcript in the paper may predict this variant to be a null variant, many other transcripts predict it to be a deep intronic variant or possibly a regulatory variant and therefore this was downgraded to a variant with some evidence of gene impact. Given the consanguinity of the family and the only evidence of variant pathogenicity being the segregation, this variant should not be scored.
Did not score this family becasue theere are 3 non segregations where affected family members only inherited 1 copy of the V528D allele.

evidence.rdfs:label: PID IV-4
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Physical assessment, vestibular and visual function
testing in deaf adults ruled out syndromic deafness because of Usher syndrome

genome-wide scan mapped the deafness trait to 10q21-22 (max LOD score of 4.0; D10S196) and fine mapping revealed a 16Mb ancestral haplotype in deaf relatives.

evidence.dc:description: There are 3 affected individuals with the genotype in this family, therefore the segregations can be counted.
evidence.rdfs:label: F9

evidence.dc:description: This is a family with 3 affecteds in recessive condition, however, the inheritance is digenic via double heterozygous mutations in PCDH15 and CDH23
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 6

member.rdfs:label: Family 6 II:2
member.detectionMethod: Panel of 84 deafness genes followed by Sanger confirmation

evidence.dc:description: Of note this family's max LOD was derived from marker D10S564 wheras the LOD for PKSR54a and PKDF139 was D10S2522
evidence.rdfs:label: PKDF70

member.rdfs:label: PKDF70-Proband
member.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis identified PCDH15 haplotype and Sanger identified 3 different variants.
member.previousTestingDescription: linkage analysis identified 3 different Pakistani families with a different PCDH15-linked haplotype.

evidence.dc:description: It is not clear which family has which LOD score in the paper, additionally, this calculated LOD score should not be counted as it is unclear as to whether all individuals in the family were sequenced. They say that unaffected and affected members of 557 families were sequenced but it's not clear how far back they went for each family.
evidence.rdfs:label: PKDF756

member.rdfs:label: PKDF756 Proband
member.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis followed by sequencing of the exons of PCDH15 and intronic flanking sequences.
member.phenotypeFreeText: severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss
member.previousTestingDescription: pure tone audiometry, electroretinography, and vestibular testing by Tandem Gait and Romberg tests

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss

evidence.dc:description: There are enough affected individuals to count this family
evidence.rdfs:label: GDSW24
PKDF139
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: clinical features of Usher syndrome type 1

evidence.dc:description: Did not include the LOD score because the digenic inheritance pattern is unlikely
evidence.rdfs:label: Chen Chinese MT-TS1 family

member.rdfs:label: III-3
member.detectionMethod: Targeted panel of 79 known deafness genes

evidence.dc:description: This famly has 3 affected family members that only have one copy of the ancestral haplotype. These 3 non-segregations provide strong support against the variant being the cause of the ARNSHL. There was also no evidence of digenic inheritance with CDH23
evidence.rdfs:label: Family A

evidence.dc:description: This family does not have enough affected individuals to be counted towards segregation scoring.
evidence.rdfs:label: KLX213

evidence.dc:description: This LOD score was candidate sequencing only and therefore should be counted as such. Additionally, the family is consanguineous
evidence.rdfs:label: PKSR54a

member.rdfs:label: PKSR54a-Proband
member.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis identified PCDH15 haplotype and Sanger identified 3 different variants.
member.phenotypeFreeText: severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss in the family
member.previousTestingDescription: linkage analysis identified 3 different Pakistani families with a different PCDH15-linked haplotype.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss in the family

evidence.dc:description: This variant was not scored because the digenic inheritance is not convincing since there was not whole exome or whole genome sequencing performed

These variants have computational and absence/low freq in gnomAD as evidence, but the only other evidence they have is that the p.T1373I variant was found in another case from this paper in trans with a frameshift variant. NO ERG's do not score

evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted sequencing of 79 known deafness genes in 125 deaf probands followed by Sanger confirmation
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Pre exclusion of mutations in GJB2, SLC26A4, MT-RNR1 by Sanger.

evidence.dc:description: This family also has a 7511T>C mutation in MT-TS1 and it is considered to be a modifier of the maternally inherited nonsyndromic hearing loss. It was not scored.
This variant has also been seen in patients with RP and therefore it cannot be scored for the nonsyndromic curation
There is only one variant as this is a consanguineous family, but it has a high LOD score as there are 5 affected individuals with the genotype in the family.

Only one homozygous consanguineous variant but it had a LOD of >2. Downgraded for consanguinity because genotype of parents was only known for 2 individuals. Additionally, this variant has been found in 2 Usher patients in a homozygous state and therefore should not be scored in this split curation as doing so would implicate that the later onset of RP was not of concern
